pr_title: Open GraalVM sources out of the box

timeline.message: Include the java.mx.project module in the tests
Parsing is tested by the integration tests extensively
Integration test to verify behavior on vm-20.3.0 snapshot
Adding header to the formatting setting
Reconstructing the core libraries with factory methods
Support for mx.*/suite.py pattern in ergonomics
Disabling check of Truffle suite due to frequent out of memory erros from javac

timeline.bodyText: I wonder - can we parse this at runtime from something? Like, maybe, mx/suite.py? It feels weird to have this information hardcoded.
timeline.author: jlahoda

replies.bodyText:
That would require mx.mx/suite.py being around. While mx is needed for execution/debugging of tests, it is not needed for opening the projects and navigating the sources right now. However, to properly resolve "standard mx libraries" we need to have information about them. That is what this file provides.
Having the information here improves out of box experience. One can git clone https://github.com/oracle/graal and immediately open and inspect the sources.
Of course, when new version of mx introduces new "standard libraries", we might need to release an update to this CoreSuite data. Possibly we could use this as default/fallback. Once mx is found/specified we could switch to its mx.mx/suite.py definitions.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: This seems to assume mx is on the IDE process'  PATH. Shouldn't it be configurable in Tools | Options, similar to maven/ant, especially when NB does not distribute mx ? If reasonable, I recommend to track it as JIRA enhancement.
timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText: True, the UI should be improved in the future. Recorded as NETBEANS-5158.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: Maybe this exclusion is worth a comment in source; why the exclusion is needed.
timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText: Unless I am mistaken this is because GraalVM (based on JDK8) contains these JARs on boot class path and we want to avoid them and rather use JARs built from the project sources.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure about this fixed bootclasspath, as there may be different JAVA_HOME defined in ~/.mx/env or mx.{projectname}/env
timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText: Let's put this on TODO list: NETBEANS-5159. If you face a buggy behavior, please describe reproducer there and turn that issue into bug.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: Silly question, but why just the 1st group ?
timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText: Running the tests I haven't seen a case where there was more groups than firstGroup. But I don't want to replace it with assert now.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: Is the 2-level parent limit hardocded in mx as well ?
timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText:
The existing sources that I am aware of are find with 2-level limit. I am not sure if the 2-level parent limit is in the {{mx}} itself or not. Scanning more deeply might have negative effect on performance. Let's leave it as it is unless
@gilles-duboscq wants to comment.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

replies.bodyText: There is indeed a 2-level limit in mx: starting from the directory in which the various repositories are checked out, the "importer" specifies if the imported suite is found at depth 1 or 2, no other depth can be specified (default is depth 1 and a "subdir" : True attribute switches the depth to 2).
replies.author: gilles-duboscq

timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText:
This is one of the reasons why special mx support is desirable. Typical NetBeans projects assume two kinds of directories - main and test. This is not true for mx there is no association of main code and test code. Tests are regular source roots with classes annotated by @Test. As such this code returns new URL[0].
Feel free to improve it, if you know how.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.author: sdedic

timeline.bodyText: processTransDeps computes transitive deps on d.owner(), isn't it computed 2nd time here for all deps not just those used in classpath construction ?
timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText: The transitive deps are processed just once. Let's make it clearer by better naming 5b589ee
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: Uh :) I meant mx already supports aarch64, maybe even i386 ?
timeline.author: sdedic

replies.bodyText: This silently assumes all developer laptops and workstations are AMD64. True for now, until Apple own processor becomes popular among devs. I guess it is going to take a bit of time and it will need deeper fixes in mx itself then.
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: better check exists != null as well
timeline.author: sdedic

timeline.bodyText: Can be somehow shared with Library implementation ?
timeline.author: sdedic

timeline.message: Removing unused argument and treating warnings as errors
Naming to indicate transitiveDeps are always processed just once
Sharing the FLAGS implementation between all three element types

timeline.bodyText: Alas, this test seems to randomly fail.
timeline.author: JaroslavTulach

replies.bodyText: Hopefully it fails only if the .mx/cache doesn't contain necessary JAR libraries (locally I have them). Let's see whether this gets fixed after 4cbe7aa
replies.author: JaroslavTulach

timeline.bodyText: Is there a better way to verify project sources are fine from a NetBeans Java Source support perspective?
timeline.author: JaroslavTulach
